name: Iona Batchelder, Director
bio: Cellist Iona Batchelder is a passionate artist and teacher who is deeply committed to fostering a genuine environment of music-making for performers, audiences, and students of all ages.

Recent collaborations include a performance with actor Rainn Wilson at the New York Times Climate Forward Event, an appointment as guest lecturer of cello at the University of California, Irvine, and recital appearances on Lincoln Center’s The Art of Wellbeing series. Ms. Batchelder is a section cellist in the Princeton Symphony Orchestra and has performed with the New York City Ballet, Orpheus Chamber Orchestra, New Jersey Symphony Orchestra, the American Symphony Orchestra, Orchestra Lumos, and the New York Classical Players.

Ms. Batchelder was a founding member of the Unison Quartet, which won an Honorary Mention award at the 2021 Bartók World Competition in Budapest, Hungary. She has performed at several festivals including Kneisel Hall, the Perlman Music Program, and the Aspen Music Festival. Always curious to explore different genres and styles of music, Ms. Batchelder has made main stage appearances with a wide variety of artists including Andrea Bocelli, Jon Batiste, Sofia Carson, and Judy Collins, and has also participated in score recording work on Netflix’s “Green Eggs and Ham.”

Ms. Batchelder was a proud recipient of a Kovner Fellowship at The Juilliard School, where she graduated with her Bachelor of Music and Master of Music degrees, both under the tutelage of Darrett Adkins, and a Juilliard Career Advancement Fellowship. She studied chamber music with artists including Joel Smirnoff, Roger Tapping, Joel Krosnick, Daniel Druckman, and Joseph Kalichstein. Deeply committed to educating the next generation, Ms. Batchelder maintains a private studio in New York City and teaches at Suzuki on the Island in Manhasset, NY.

name: Ariel Horowitz
bio: Ariel Horowitz is a violinist, composer/songwriter, and educator whose work bridges performance, teaching, and community-engaged practice. Hailed by The Washington Post as “sweetly lyrical,” she maintains an active national and international career as a soloist and chamber musician, performing repertoire that spans the Western classical canon alongside original compositions, songwriting, and improvisation. She is currently represented worldwide by Bright Shiny Things.

As a performer, Horowitz appears regularly as a soloist, chamber musician, and collaborator in a wide range of contexts, from traditional concert halls to interdisciplinary and community-centered venues. She performs with ensembles including Sybarite5, Vision Duo, and Jupiter Symphony Chamber Players, and has appeared at venues such as Joe’s Pub, Merkin Hall, the Kennedy Center Millennium Stage, and the Strathmore Center for the Arts.

Horowitz is also a dedicated educator, and has held faculty appointments at Mount Holyoke College and the Chamber Music Center of New York, where she coaches pre-college chamber music ensembles. She is the Founder and Artistic Director of the Heartbeat Music Project, a tuition-free music education and Diné cultural education program serving Navajo youth. Heartbeat operates by invitation and in deep collaboration with Diné elders, educators, and knowledge keepers, with cultural and language programming led by community-based leadership. Through this work, Horowitz leads interdisciplinary teams of artists and educators and engages in culturally responsive practice grounded in listening, respect, and shared ownership.
Horowitz holds degrees from Yale School of Music and The Juilliard School, where her primary teachers included Ani Kavafian, Itzhak Perlman, and Catherine Cho.

name: Jennifer Ahn
bio: Jennifer Ahn is a New York City-based violinist originally from Omaha, whose career spans North America, Europe, and Asia. She has performed at renowned international venues such as Carnegie Hall, Suntory Hall, and the Holland Performing Arts Center. Ahn made her solo debut with the Omaha Symphony at age 11 and has since performed with various orchestras, including the Ottawa Chamber Symphony and the New York Youth Symphony.

Ahn is an enthusiastic artist who has been featured in the Manhattan School of Music's Centennial Celebration Concert Series and has performed with the Chamber Music Society at Lincoln Center. She has also participated in several music festivals and programs, winning the inaugural Duo Competition at the Music Academy of the West. Her upcoming 2025–2026 season includes performances with the New York Classical Players, the Princeton Symphony, and the Frisson Ensemble.

Her musical journey began at the Omaha Conservatory of Music, where she studied with Ruth Meints. She holds Bachelor's and Master's degrees from the Manhattan School of Music, where she studied with Pinchas Zukerman and Patinka Kopec. Ahn is also dedicated to music education, serving as a Teaching Artist for the New York Pops’ PopsEd program, a mentor for the New York Youth Symphony, and maintaining a private studio.

name: Hannah Burnett
bio: Hannah Burnett is a New York-based freelance violist who started playing at age three in Waco, Texas. She has performed internationally at venues such as Carnegie Hall and the Royal Concertgebouw. Burnett is the Principal Violist of the Washington Heights Chamber Orchestra and a member of the New York Classical Players and the Princeton Symphony Orchestra. She also frequently performs with NOVUS Trinity, the American Ballet Theater orchestra, and Riverside Symphony.

As an enthusiastic chamber musician, Burnett has attended Kneisel Hall and Yellow Barn Festivals. She was a founding member of the Unison Quartet, which participated in the Juilliard String Quartet Seminar, held quartet residencies at the Perlman Music Program and the Aspen Center for Advanced String Quartet Studies, and reached the finals of the 2021 Bartok World Competition in Budapest. She has received coaching from members of the Juilliard String Quartet and collaborated with notable artists like Natasha Brofsky, Anthony Marwood, Gilbert Kalish, Krzysztof Chorzelski, Janine Jansen, and Donald Weilerstein.

Beyond her performance career, Hannah Burnett teaches at the Greenwich Suzuki Academy and runs a private studio in New York City. She earned two degrees from Juilliard, where she studied with Roger Tapping and Misha Amory, and was awarded the Kovner Fellowship.

name: Samuel DeCaprio
bio: Cellist Samuel DeCaprio is a dynamic performer and teacher based in the Tri-State area. Among his numerous honors, he received a Norman Benzaquen Career Advancement Grant from The Juilliard School, won the Aldo Parisot Prize at the Yale School of Music and the prestigious Performer's Certificate from the Eastman School of Music, along with top prizes from the Arlington, Eastern Connecticut Symphony, National Federation of Music Clubs, and William C. Byrd competitions. His New York debut featured the North American premiere of Grażyna Bacewicz’s Cello Concerto No. 2 with the Juilliard Orchestra and conductor David Robertson in Alice Tully Hall. Appearing across the globe as a soloist and chamber musician, he has been featured on prominent radio programs including WQXR New York, WFMT Chicago, NPR, and WCNI, and has recorded for Delos, ECM Records, MSR Classics, and Nonesuch Records. He has played as a substitute with the New York Philharmonic, New York City Ballet, and Princeton Symphony Orchestra.

A passionate chamber musician, DeCaprio’s festival appearances include Ravinia Steans Music Institute, IMS Prussia Cove Open Chamber Music, Les Rencontres Musicales de Noyers-sur-Serein, Domaine Forget, Kneisel Hall, Lake George, Meadowmount, and Orford Musique, and collaborated with renowned artists, including Atar Arad, Paul Biss, Natasha Brofsky, Steven Doane, Vladimir Feltsman, Joseph Lin, Daniel Phillips, David Shifrin, Barry Snyder, and Irma Vallecillo. In 2022, DeCaprio founded the Arazzo Music Festival—an annual chamber music festival focused on bringing free high-caliber concerts and educational events to his home state of Connecticut. DeCaprio holds degrees from UConn, Eastman, Mannes, Yale, and Juilliard. His principal teachers include Joel Krosnick, Aldo Parisot, Marcy Rosen, Steven Doane, and Kangho Lee.
